questions.text: A 6-year boy is brought to eye OPD by his parents complaining of inward deviation of his left eye. His teacher complains of he making too many mistakes copying from the board. The first step in the evaluation of this child?

options.label: A
options.text: Visual acuity and refraction under atropine ointment

options.label: C
options.text: Visual acuity and refraction under homatropine

questions.correct_answer: A. Visual acuity and refraction under atropine ointment
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Visual acuity and refraction under atropine ointment The first test to be done in a patient of squint is checking for visual acuity and refraction under full cycloplegia . The cycloplegic of choice in less than 8 years is atropine ointment . The complaint of making too many mistakes points towards a blurred vision for far. Thus the foremost step is checking for refraction under cycloplegic cover.

Highyeild:

Convergent strabismus (esodeviation) These are generally more common in childhood and hypermetropes. Classification Esodeviation can be classified according to the underlying aetiopathogenesis and according to the type of Deviation Type Criterion Nonaccommodative : Esotropia at distance = near fixation; no change with refractive correction Accommodative: Refractive (associated with high hypermetropia): Esotropia at distance ≥ near fixation; fully corrected by hyperopic correction for distance Non Refractive (high AC/A ratio)/(high accommodation convergence): Esotropia at near fixation > distance or manifesting only at near; fully corrected by an additional hyperopic correction for near work (BIFOCAL GLASSES) Mixed Partially accommodative : Esotropia partly corrected by the use of refractive correction TREATMENT: ROOOP Refractive error correction Occlude normal eye Orthoptic exercises Operation Prism therapy

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B . Direct cover test - A cover test or cover-uncover test is an objective determination of the presence and amount of ocular deviation. It is typically performed by orthoptists Option: C . Visual acuity and refraction under homatropine - under atropine in case of a child. Option: D . Maddox rod test - The Maddox rod test can be used to subjectively detect and measure latent, manifest, horizontal or vertical strabismus for near and distance. The test is based on the principle of diplopic projection.

Extraedge:

questions.text: What is the principle of the Maddox rod test?

options.label: B
options.text: Principle of converting white light to red light

questions.explanation:
Solution:

Principle of diploic projection The Maddox rod test is used to measure both heterotropias as well heterophorias . Maddox rod is made of parallel glass cylinders (usually of red colour) set together in a metallic disc. This converts a point source of light to a linear image formed perpendicular to the axis of the cylinders . The position of the streak in relation to the image of the light source seen by a fellow eye gives the amount of deviation. This test is based on the principle of diploic projection . MADDOX ROD AND TORCH LIGHT

Highyeild:

The Maddox rod test is used to measure both heterotropias as well heterophorias . Maddox rod is made of parallel glass cylinders (usually of red colour) set together in a metallic disc. This converts a point source of light to a linear image formed perpendicular to the axis of the cylinders . The position of the streak in relation to the image of the light source seen by a fellow eye gives the amount of deviation. This test is based on the principle of diploic projection. INTERPRETATION:

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Principle of converting white light to red light - no, there is no relation of red light specifically in the Maddox rod test. Option: C. Refixation of the deviating eye - no, Maddox rod is an investigation which does not involve refixation, unlike the cover uncovers test. Option: D. Neutralizing tropias only - that is incorrect.

Extraedge:

WHAT IS THE MADDOX WING TEST? The deviation in near vision is conveniently tested by the Maddox wing test, in which the patient looks through the two-slit holes in the eyepieces of the instrument. The fields which are exposed to each eye are separated by a diaphragm in such a way that they glide tangentially into each other. The right eye sees a white arrow pointing vertically upwards and a red arrow pointing horizontally to the left, whereas the left eye sees a horizontal row of figures in white and a vertical row in red. These are calibrated to be read in degrees of deviation. Both the arrow pointing to the horizontal row of figures and the arrow pointing to the vertical row should be at zero; any deviation indicates an eso- or exophoria or a hyperphoria, the amount of which can be read off on the scale.

questions.text: A patient presents to you with a complaint that his friends say his left eye seems deviated. You examined him to find no change in head posture, visual acuity unaided being 6/6 in R/E and 6/18 in L/E. On checking for pupillary reflex, both pupils are briskly reacting to light. On Hirschberg corneal reflex testing the reflex is central in R/E and on pupillary in L/E. The fundi of both eyes are normal. What is the approx amount of deviation of the left eye in Prism Diopters?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

30PD The Hirschberg corneal reflex test gives you a rough estimation of the degree of deviation of the eye either in eso or exo. The normal corneal reflex is in the centre of the pupil or slightly nasal. The light reflex falling on the pupillary border means 15 degrees of deviation, at the limbus means 45 degrees of deviation and in between the two suggests 30 degrees of deviation on either side corresponding to esotropia and exotropia. One degree of deviation = 2 Prism Diopters . So the answer is approx 30PD. This test gives a rough estimate of deviation.

Highyeild:

HIRSCHBERG CORNEAL REFLEX A rough indication of the angle of the squint can be obtained from the position of the corneal reflex when light is thrown into the eye from a distance of about 60 cm with the ophthalmoscope or a focused light beam from a torch. The patient is asked to look at the light; an infant does this reflexly. In the fixing eye, the corneal reflex will be in the centre of the pupil , slightly to the inner side if there is a large angle kappa and to the outer side if there is a negative angle kappa. The light is observed to be decentred in the squinting eye. If the reflex is about halfway between the centre of the pupil and the corneal margin, there is a deviation of about 20° and if it is at the corneal margin, about 45° . Roughly 1 mm deviation of the corneal light reflex is equivalent to 7° of deviation . This test gives only an approximate estimation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A . 15PD - 30PD is not the correct answer. Option: C . 45 PD - 30PD is not the correct answer. Option: D . More than 45 PD - 30PD is not the correct answer.

Extraedge:

The angle of deviation of the squinting eye can also be measured on the perimeter or the tangent scale; in either case, the patient fixes the central point with the good eye and the surgeon carries a light along the arc of the perimeter or the arm of the tangent scale until the corneal reflex thus obtained is centred on the pupil of the squinting eye . The angle at which this occurs is the angle of the squint

questions.text: All of the following are objective tests for heterotropia except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Maddox rod test The Maddox rod test is a subjective test for heterotropia as well as heterophoria. It is based on the principle of diplopia . This is useful only for small angles of deviation because when large prisms are used it is difficult for the patient to see both the red line and the fixation light simultaneously. The Remaining three tests in the above options give an objective assessment of heterotopias.

Highyeild:

The Maddox rod test is used to measure both heterotropias as well heterophorias . Maddox rod is made of parallel glass cylinders (usually of red colour) set together in a metallic disc. This converts a point source of light to a linear image formed perpendicular to the axis of the cylinders . The position of the streak in relation to the image of the light source seen by a fellow eye gives the amount of deviation. This test is based on the principle of diploic projection. INTERPRETATION:

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Prism bar cover test (PBCT) - The prism cover test (PCT) is an objective measurement and the gold standard in measuring strabismus, i.e. ocular misalignment, or a deviation of the eye. Option: B. Krimsky's corneal reflex test - Krimsky test. The prism is placed in front of the deviating eye to correct the deviation of the corneal light reflex. Option: C. Perimeter method - In order to find the perimeter or distance around the rectangle, we need to add up all four side lengths. This can be done efficiently by simply adding the length and the width, and then multiplying this sum by two since there are two of each side length.

Extraedge:

KRIMSKY TEST: Modified Krimsky test of estimating deviation. A decentered corneal reflection in the left eye (A) is gradually centred by placing progressively stronger prisms in front of the fixating right eye (B, C). DEVIATION is measured directly in Dioptres.

questions.text: Which one of the following ocular alignment tests don’t require foveal fixation in the deviated eye for quantification of the angle of the strabismus?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

The Krimsky test Krimsky test uses prisms over the fixating eye to centre the light reflex over the pupil in the deviating eye . Foveal fixation is not required in this test . It is used to estimate the size of the angle of the squint in patients with a blind or deeply amblyopic eye with or without eccentric fixation.

Highyeild:

KRIMSKY TEST : Modified Krimsky test of estimating deviation. A decentered corneal reflection in the left eye (A) is gradually centred by placing progressively stronger prisms in front of the fixating right eye (B, C). DEVIATION is measured directly in Dioptres. PROCEDURE : To perform the test, the patient is asked to fixate on a point light and prisms of increasing strength ( with apex towards the direction of a manifest squint) are placed in front of the normal fixating eye till the corneal reflex is centred in the squinting eye. It has the advantage of being used in eyes with very low visual acuity or the eye that has lost central fixation

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Cover - uncover test with a prism - not the correct option. Option: B. Alternate - cover test with a prism - not the correct option. Option: C. Simultaneous prism cover test - not the correct option.

Extraedge:

Prism bar test: This is the most commonly used method in routine clinical practice . The angle of deviation can be measured with the prism cover test using prisms of different strengths (either loose prisms or mounted prism bars) in front of one eye with the apex pointing towards the deviation and repeating the test till the corrective movement of the eye is neutralized. The strength of the prism which is needed for neutralization gives the objective angle of deviation. In case one eye is blind , the Krimsky method of neutralization is followed , where prisms are placed in front of the ‘seeing’ eye which fixates a light target and increasing strengths of prisms are applied till the corneal reflex is centred in the ‘blind’ eye

questions.text: The most appropriate surgical option for infantile esotropia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Bimedial Recessions surgery of esotropia must provide either weakening of medial rectus muscles (recession) or strengthening of lateral rectus muscles (resection). Recessions always have greater effect than resection of the same amount. Thus bimedial recession is generally performed before bilateral resection.

Highyeild:

The safest operations for general use are a recession or a resection of the appropriate muscle . There is often a considerable deviation so surgery may be required in both eyes . Free tenotomy of the medial rectus tendon and its expansions into the tenon capsule is usually followed by divergence and retraction of the caruncle and plica semilunaris owing to the failure of reattachment to the globe and is no longer recommended. A partial tenotomy of the lateral rectus muscle, however, is sometimes permissible but again not generally recommended. The medial rectus should not be recessed more than 5 mm, i.e. not beyond the physiological equator, lest weak convergence occurs leading to discomfort in reading and near work and headaches.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Unilateral recess - resect operation on non dominant eye may be performed in patients who have failed to respond to amblyopia treatment. Thus most appropriate surgical option is bimedial recession. So, Unilateral recess-resect - this is not the correct option. Option: C . Bimedial resection Option: D. Bilateral resection - clearly not the correct option.

questions.text: All of the following are associated with congenital exotropia except?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Overaction of inferior obliques Overacting inferior obliques is associated with congenital esotropia and not exotropia . Characteristic features of congenital exotropia are large angle constant exodeviation (mostly more than 35PD ), poor fusion, and a higher incidence of amblyopia . Craniofacial abnormalities, ocular albinism, and cerebral palsy are associated with congenital exotropia. Treatment consists of amblyopia therapy at the earliest and bilateral lateral rectus recession after 6 months of age and before 24 months .

Highyeild:

Congenital exotropia Presents before age 6 months; Large-angle constant exotropia (>35 prism diopters); Often associated with neurologic impairment or craniofacial disorders; These children usually alternate fixation; The refractive error is similar to that of the general population; Treatment: Surgery early in life .

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. Craniofacial abnormality Option B. Ocular albinism Option: C. Cerebral palsy is due to abnormal brain development, often before birth. Symptoms include exaggerated reflexes, floppy or rigid limbs and involuntary motions. These appear in early childhood. Long-term treatment includes physical and other therapies, drugs and sometimes surgery.

Extraedge:

Infantile (or congenital) esotropia Equal sex distribution/Present by 6 months of age/Family history of strabismus is common; Incidence is higher in patients with a history of prematurity, cerebral palsy, hydrocephalus, and other neurological disorders; Maternal cigarette smoking and low birth rate are associated risk factors High incidence of amblyopia (40-72%); Present by 6 months of age; Large angle of esodeviation (usually ≥ 30 prism diopters) Treatment: Nonsurgical : Correct amblyopia before surgery (patching, atropine eye drops) Surgical : Surgical alignment earlier than age 2 is associated with better sensory binocular fusion potential.

questions.text: Most conspicuous symptom of intermittent exotropia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Photophobia The usual history of a child with intermittent exotropia is that the child closes one eye in bright light . The bright light adversely affects the amplitude of fusional convergence in patients who maintain a delicate balance between exophoria and intermittent exotropia , causing them to close one eye.

Highyeild:

Intermittent exotropia: The most common divergent strabismus in childhood Onset usually before age 5 Deviation becomes manifest during times of visual inattention, fatigue, or stress Exposure to bright light often causes a reflex closure of one eye Amblyopia is uncommon.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Micropsia is a less common symptom of intermittent exotropia. Option: C. Asthenopic symptoms occur in the beginning but later on the child becomes asymptomatic due to the development of sensory adaptation. Option: D. Transient diplopia occurs in the beginning but ARC and suppression develop quickly to prevent the child from diplopia.

questions.text: A patient with manifest esodeviation undergoes Worth’s four dot test. He sees four lights i.e. one red, two green, and one white). What does the interpretation mean?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Patient has developed ARC If a patient sees all four lights in the presence of manifest squint = ARC ARC- Abnormal retinal correspondence= It is the establishment of a new working relationship between the fovea of one eye and the extrafoveal region of another eye. It is a binocular phenomenon.

Highyeild:

In Worth's four dot test patient wears red-green glasses with red in front of R/E and green over L/E and views a box with four lights- one red, two green, and one white . Red can be seen through only R/E & green through L/E & white light can be seen with both eyes. The results are interpreted depending on the patient’s observation as If a patient sees all four lights in the absence of squint = Normal binocular vision If a patient sees all four lights in the presence of manifest squint = ARC Only two red lights are seen = left suppression Only three green lights are seen = right suppression Three green lights and two red lights are een alternatively = alternating suppression Five lights are seen ( 2 red & 3 green) = diplopia

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A. If a patient sees all four lights in the absence of squint = Normal binocular vision. Option: A. patient has manifest esodeviation. Option: C. Patient has manifest squint so cannot be malingering Option: D. Five lights seen ( 2 red & 3 green) = diplopia.

Extraedge:

In Comitant squint , diplopia is not seen esp. in children < 8 years because of suppression of squinted eyes. This can lead to Amblyopia/Lazy eye known as strabismic amblyopia. Treatment: Occlude normal eye as soon as possible.

questions.text: Praveen, came to OPD as a third-year resident. A resident found that the patient had an apparent convergent squint with the prominent epicanthic fold. Which of the following conditions will be associated with the following condition?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Negative Angle Kappa In pseudostrabismus (apparent squint), the visual axes are in fact parallel , but the eyes seem to have a squint: Pseudoesotropia or apparent convergent squint Prominent epicanthal fold (which covers the normally visible nasal aspect of the globe and gives a false impression of esotropia). A negative angle of kappa is seen. Pseudoexotropia or apparent divergent squint may be associated with Hypertelorism, a condition of wide two eyes (i.e., wide IPD), and Positive angle kappa.

Highyeild:

In pseudostrabismus (apparent squint), the visual axes are in fact parallel, but the eyes seem to have a squint: Pseudoesotropia or apparent convergent squint Prominent epicanthal fold (which covers the normally visible nasal aspect of the globe and gives a false impression of esotropia). A negative angle of kappa is seen. Pseudoexotropia or apparent divergent squint may be associated with Hypertelorism , a condition of wide two eyes (i.e., wide IPD), and Positive angle kappa.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: B. Hypertelorism, a condition of wide two eyes (i.e., wide IPD), and Positive angle kappa. Option: C. Hypermetropia - Hypermetropia is also referred to as hyperopia or long-sightedness or far-sightedness. Hypermetropia is the condition of the eyes where the image of a nearby object is formed behind the retina. Here, the light is focused behind the retina instead of focusing on the retina. Option: D. Retinopathy of prematurity Retinopathy of prematurity (ROP) is an eye disorder caused by abnormal blood vessel growth in the light sensitive part of the eyes (retina) of premature infants. ROP generally affects infants born before week 31 of pregnancy and weighing 2.75 pounds (about 1,250 grams) or less at birth.

Extraedge:

KAPPA ANGLE Angle kappa is defined as the angle between the visual axis (the line connecting the fixation point with the fovea) and the pupillary axis (the line that perpendicularly passes through the entrance pupil and the centre of curvature of the cornea).

questions.text: Which of the following is the cause of concomitant squint?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

All of the above Concomitant squints are not caused by nerve palsy or muscle paralysis as is the case with incomitant squints. Concomitant squint is caused by a number of causes like Option A - 1) Refractive error Option B - 2) Anisometropia Option C - 3) Prolonged use of wrong spectacles Corneal opacity Lenticular opacity Optic atrophy Macular diseases The causes from 4-7 cause squint by preventing simultaneous perception to develop and thus preventing the fusion to develop & binocularity is not established.

Highyeild:

AETIOLOGY OF INCOMITANT SQUINT: COMITANT SQUINT: In comitant strabismus , the visual axes, although abnormally directed, retain their abnormal relation to each other in all movements of the eyes. The final lower pathway in the efferent tracts controlling ocular movements is undisturbed(e no paralysis and no restriction) , but either the visual impressions arriving at the cortex from one eye are defective or the fusional reflexes have not or have been weakly developed and have broken down so that an ocular deviation results. The cause or causes of this failure are unknown . Many contributory factors in the aetiology of comitant strabismus are: Defective vision in one eye , such as high ametropia, opacities in the media or ocular disease If the defect exists from birth or early life, the cortical cells normally subserving both eyes may never develop binocular connections. Disturbances in muscular equilibrium , usually due to a congenital mal-insertion or defective development of one or more of the extrinsic muscles , may act in the same way, with the squint perhaps being preceded by a period of heterophoria during which fusion was maintained. A change in the normal balance between accommodation and convergence The continuous effort of accommodation in the hypermetrope to see clearly, even in the distance, stimulates convergence to a greater degree than is compatible with binocular fixation.

Random:

Explanation for incorrect options: - Option: A - 1) Refractive error Option: B - 2) Anisometropia Option: C - 3) Prolonged use of wrong spectacles All these can cause comitant squint.

Extraedge:

AETIOLOGY OF INCOMITANT SQUINT: Congenital developmental abnormalities Trauma Infections Neoplastic Vascular (MOST COMMON CAUSE IS 6TH NERVE PALSY DUE TO VASCULAR CAUSE) Inflammatory disorders
